name: मुक्ति | Mukti - Liberation in Song
description:
Oftentimes, the most powerful revolutions begin in verse. 
With stirring narratives and emotional melodies, Mukti – Liberation in Song invites audiences to embark on an introspective journey, guided by the verses of poets who dared to dream beyond boundaries. The programme juxtaposes live performances of classical and folk compositions in multiple languages with immersive narration. Enhanced by a simulcast slideshow that spotlights the rich tapestry of Indian poetry, this event explores the perennial quest for freedom. 
From Tyagaraja’s desire to break free from worldly attachments to Akka Mahadevi’s defiance of patriarchal norms, each performance encapsulates a unique facet of liberation. Basavanna and Chokkamela’s verses resonate with resistance against caste barriers, advocating universal equality. Kabir’s timeless words soar with a similar spirit, calling upon souls to shatter dogmatic chains. 
This evening, we honor the enduring spirit of Mukti and celebrate the poets whose voices envisioned a world where freedom isn’t just a political concept, but a universally human truth.

name: Nehru’s India in the World
description:
Scholars of international relations, political thought, and India’s diplomatic history continue to debate the meaning and relevance of non-alignment in India’s foreign policy today. The origins of these debates lie in Jawaharlal Nehru’s articulation of non-alignment at the height of the Cold War, a concept both resolute and ambiguous. 
In this talk, Dr. Swapna Kona Nayudu will draw on her acclaimed book, The Nehru Years: An International History of Indian Non-Alignment (Cambridge University Press UK, Juggernaut Books India), to explore how India’s approach to international affairs and the United Nations now understood in summary as non-alignment. Based on meticulous archival research in multiple languages, her work uncovers India’s diplomatic and peacekeeping contributions in pivotal global events such as the Korean War, the Suez Crisis, the Hungarian Revolution, and the Congo Crisis. 
Tracing the evolution of non-alignment from Nehru’s time to the present, Dr. Kona Nayudu will examine its contested meaning and its influence on India’s position as the only non-aligned founding member of the UN. 
Dr. Kona Nayudu will be in conversation with Jahnavi Phalkey. The discussion will be followed by a Q&A session with the audience.

location.name: Bangalore International Centre, 7, 4th Main Road, Domlur II Stage, Bangalore, Karnataka, 560071, India

name: Partition: Memory, Responsibility & Voice
description:
How do we honour truths without exploitation or erasure? 
This panel discussion will explore how the chapter of Partition is remembered, who holds the responsibility of preserving its stories, and what it means to give them an honest voice. Through literature, oral testimony, archives, or immersive media, each speaker has engaged with histories marked by silence, trauma, and survival. In this session, they will reflect on the choices they have made: to amplify certain voices, to tell different stories with care, and to avoid reducing complex truths into simplified narratives. 
At the heart of this conversation is a shared responsibility; not only as writers, educators, or artists, but as individuals shaped by inherited memory. As Partition fades from lived memory, this panel asks how the stories we carry today might shape the understanding of future generations, and the ways they remember, question, and imagine.

name: Bahinabai Chaudhari - The Voice of the Soil
description:
From the furrows of the earth rises a voice: quiet, wise, and enduring. 
Bahinabai: Echoes of the Earth is a Bharatanatyam performance that brings to life the deeply moving poetry of Bahinabai Chaudhari, a farmer-poet whose simple, profound verses speak of toil, tenderness, and inner strength.  
Conceptualized and performed by Vaishnavi Dhore, this piece blends classical dance with Marathi ovi (verse), folk rhythms, and classical music to reimagine Bahinabai’s world. With evocative storytelling and expressive movement, this performance bridges the rural and the urban, the past and the present. 
For the everyday woman is a philosopher, poet, and pioneer!

name: Feelings Big & Small
description:
Little hearts have the biggest feelings. 
In this engaging workshop, children (aged 4+) and their parents are welcomed into a shared space where feelings become easier to see, name, and understand. Through storytime, music, movement, and art, children are guided to tune into their inner world. Kids will dance through their moods, draw out their feelings, and playfully explore what it means to be calm, frustrated, or excited. 
Alongside, parents will discover tools to better understand their child’s emotional world and connect more deeply. There will be space for questions and discussions on child behaviour. 
All materials are provided, including colours, worksheets, and take-home resources. 
With calming breath-work, openhearted conversations, and creative activities, this 90-minute session turns emotional learning into a shared family story. One that continues long after the workshop ends!

name: Music of the Kirana Gharana
description:
A single note can carry centuries of devotion. 
The Kirana Gharana tradition of Hindustani classical music reveals itself slowly. Like dawn breaking across a silent sky, it is characterised by a meditative approach. Known for its graceful meend (glides) and evocative sargams (musical phrases), this musical evening invites deep listening and quiet awe. 
Acclaimed vocalist Pandit Milind Chittal brings the essence of this lineage to life. With his masterful control and emotive phrasing, he leads audiences through the delicate unfolding of ragas, where each swara (note) holds a world of feeling, and every silence has meaning. 
This is more than a performance; it’s a conversation across time, held in melody and breath. 
Let the music find its way to where words cannot reach.

name: Skandaanubhavam - The World of Blissful Consciousness
description:
A poet’s longing, a saint’s surrender, and a seeker’s bliss. 
Blending the lyrical storytelling of Harikatha with the expressive grace of Bharatanatyam, this performance is a humble offering to Lord Muruga. The Tamil deity has stirred poets, saints, and seekers for centuries. At its heart, Skandaanubhavam is rooted in ‘Atma Anubhava’, the intimate, transformative experiences that lie behind the poetry. These are not just tales from the past, but living moments of devotion that continue to resonate. 
This evocative production invites audiences on a journey through his many stories. Harikatha offers historical, philosophical, and devotional context through flowing rhythm and spoken word. Bharatanatyam, with its sculptural beauty and intricate abhinaya, draws us into the inner terrain of yearning, valor, and spiritual revelation. 
This is an evening of meditation in motion, and a quiet call to the divine within.

name: The Indo-Pacific Outlook: An Australian Perspective
description:
As global power dynamics continue to shift, the Indo-Pacific sits at the heart of a rapidly evolving strategic and economic landscape. In this timely and wide-ranging session, Peter Varghese, former Australian Foreign Secretary and High Commissioner to India, offers a perspective shaped by decades of diplomacy and deep engagement with the region. 
His address will explore the complex forces redefining the Indo-Pacific: from the sharpening rivalry between the US and China, to China’s expanding influence and the evolving policy direction in Washington. The session will also examine how key regional players (India, Japan, Korea, Indonesia) are shaping their own responses to these pressures, and what this means for the broader security of the region. 
Alongside geopolitics, the conversation will turn to trade tensions, economic nationalism, and the slowing pace of globalization; factors that now cast long shadows over our economic future. Can traditional regional institutions hold, or will more agile, interest-based minilateral groups take their place? 
Following his presentation, Peter Varghese will converse with Latha Reddy, Nitin Pai, and Ranjan Mathai. The evening concludes with an audience Q&A, inviting reflections on a region that will shape the 21st century.

name: Driving Elephants
description:
26 minutes | English with subtitles | 2019 
Forests inspire awe, yet fragmentation, monocultures, and urban sprawl disrupt their balance, driving biodiversity loss and human-elephant conflict (HWC). Elephants, as ecosystem engineers, adapt by moving through both wild and cultivated lands, exposing the blurred lines of modern landscapes. 
Set in regions like Bannerghatta, Cauvery, and Mysore, where A Rocha India works closely with communities and frontline staff, Driving Elephants documents the fatal consequences faced by free-ranging elephants when they venture into human spaces. Male elephants, in particular, are increasingly pushed to the fringes, navigating traffic, raiding crops at night, and forming risky coalitions in search of survival. 
With over 730 humans and 336 elephants dying annually due to HWC, this crisis demands more than tolerance; it calls for empathy, equity, and space for all. The screening of Driving Elephants is an invitation to reflect on coexistence in these shared landscapes and to reimagine a future where people and elephants can thrive together. 
The screening will be followed by an audience Q&A session with Avinash Krishnan

name: The Open Couple
description:
Language: English 
When the rules of love are rewritten, what’s left standing? 
Dario Fo’s The Open Couple is a bold, sharp, and darkly comic exploration of modern relationships pushed to the edge. What begins as a provocative experiment (a husband proposing an open marriage) quickly spirals into chaos, confrontation, and unexpected revelations. 
Set against the backdrop of shifting gender roles and social expectations, the play peels back the layers of a marriage unravelling. With biting wit and disarming vulnerability, Fo exposes the emotional toll of jealousy, the absurdity of control, and the fragile line between freedom and fear. The couple’s battles are fast, funny, and painfully familiar, as they try to navigate the messy terrain of love, power, and identity. 
Through its rapid dialogue and theatrical twists, The Open Couple holds up a mirror to our ideas of commitment and connection; asking what we’re really seeking when we ask for more. 
A deeply human comedy that leaves room for both laughter and reckoning. 
Credits:
Writer : Dario Fo
Director : Faraz Khan
Creative Producer : Ragini Roychowdhury
Actors : Vaishali Bisht & Rohan Joshi

name: Un.Divided Identities
description:
Exhibition Opening: 11 am | Wednesday, 6 Aug
Exhibition Timings: 11 am – 8 pm
Exhibition on show until: 8 pm | Sunday, 10 Aug

4 pm | Saturday, 9 Aug (followed by a ‘meet the team’ at 5 pm)

Partition: Memory, Responsibility, and Voice (Panel Discussion): 11 am – 12:30 pm | Saturday, 9 Aug | Auditorium 
Un.Divided Identities is an interactive choice-based digital exhibition on the 1947 Partition of the Indian subcontinent. Originally launched online in 2022 by ReReeti in partnership with the British Council and Glasgow Life Museums, this exhibition is now being reimagined as a physical, immersive experience. It is especially relevant for young people who have only ever encountered Partition through textbook chapters and distorted narratives. 
Curated by ReReeti, designed by Aditi Dhamija, and in collaboration with the Bangalore International Centre, this exhibition urges participants to deeply feel the emotional weight of forced, mass migration. The digital interactives serve as the core touch point, but the stories extend beyond the screen. Spilling into the physical space as tactile, atmospheric, and visually compelling encounters, visitors navigate through stories of displacement – stories based on real accounts of families. You will face difficult choices on behalf of characters, driven by fear, survival, and the need to protect their families. 
While Partition impacted families across the subcontinent, its realities are often distant in southern India. This exhibition opens space for reflection and conversation, prompting visitors to connect personally with questions of identity, loss, memory, and inter-generational resilience. 
The hope is to change how future generations choose to carry our history forward.

name: Aah! Aha! Ha-ha!
description:
Are we teaching children what to think, or how to think? When our children focus on rote learning and exam-based academic progress, how do we nurture the inventive Indian who can fuel the imagination of the world with creativity, critical thinking and problem-solving? What if classrooms became labs of imagination, not factories of repetition? 
These are the questions that the Agastya International Foundation set out to answer 25 years ago, by designing a curiosity-driven, experiential learning model that has transformed education across India. Today, their vision of sparking curiosity, nurturing creativity and instilling confidence and caring has impacted over 25 million schoolchildren and 300,000 teachers in government schools across 23 Indian States. 
An acclaimed new book from Penguin Random House, The Moving of Mountains traces Agastya’s extraordinary journey in reshaping the classroom by replacing rote learning with hands-on experiments, creative projects and interactive models in science, art and ecology. 
Join us in a discussion of why this powerful vision for curiosity-driven, experiential learning is critical to the future of India, and has caught the imagination of scientists, industry leaders, educationists and policy makers alike. 
The discussion will be followed by a Q&A session.

name: Confessions of a Lobbyist
description:
Insider accounts from political aides, bureaucrats, and diplomats have long illuminated the workings of power—but even more enigmatic were the lobbyists. Operating in the shadows, often invisible to public scrutiny, they were intimately privy to clandestine negotiations, back-channel discussions, and subtle bureaucratic skirmishes. In his new roman-à-clef For No Reason At All, Ramjee Chandran shines a light on this hidden world. 
Chandran—well‑known in Bangalore as a journalist, publisher, and podcaster—has, until now, remained silent about his time as a lobbyist in 1980s New Delhi, a pivotal era just before major economic reforms took hold. 
Drawing from real events, the novel charts the journey of a young lobbyist caught in a high-stakes conflict over silicon metal—a material deemed strategically vital. Central to the drama is Metkem Silicon, which, in collaboration with the Indian Institute of Science in Bangalore, devoted 17 years to developing indigenous silicon metal technology. Yet their efforts collided with a rival scheme spearheaded by the Department of Electronics, which wanted to bypass local innovation and import U.S. technology. 
What ensued was a four‑year bureaucratic war: media leaks, secret memorandums, and the covert involvement of the Soviets and other intelligence agencies—culminating in a final decision placed in the hands of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi. 
Set against the backdrop of Cold War Delhi on the cusp of liberalisation, the novel paints a vivid portrait of a nation—and capital—torn between ideologies and ambitions. The Soviet Union may have vanished, lobbyists have receded from public corridors, and few can claim first‑hand knowledge of that era. 
In Confessions of a Lobbyist, Siddharth Raja—a lawyer, historian, and bibliophile—sits down with Ramjee Chandran to peel back the layers of this story, offering an insider’s glimpse into a world that feels at once distant and disarmingly relevant.

name: Sounds from the Library (#4)
description:
Sounds From The Library returns for its fourth edition! 
An intimate evening where conversation and performance intertwine in the cozy, listener-focused space of the BIC library. This hybrid series spotlights emerging voices from the Indian music scene, all past longlisted artists from the Toto Awards for Music. 
This edition hosts Krameri from Vadodara, who brings a moody, atmospheric blend of electro, dance, and alt-pop, a soundscape that’s as textured as it is emotional. Sharing the stage is Lettisha, a Trivandrum-based artist whose fresh take on contemporary hip-hop and R&B is equal parts soulful and sharp. 
More than a gig, Sounds From The Library invites audiences into the creative lives of the artists; offering insight into their inspirations, processes, and personal journeys. With music that moves and conversations that linger, this is a rare chance to experience live performance in its most thoughtful form.

name: Beyond the Horizon
description:
India’s celestial aspirations continue to reach new heights! In the wake of the successful AXIOM-4 mission, the nation takes yet another bold step toward securing its place among the global leaders in space exploration. This engaging discussion delves deep into the implications of the AXIOM-4 mission and its role in India’s broader space ambitions. 
With esteemed space scientist Dr. B R Guruprasad and senior aerospace journalist Chethan Kumar, we decode this mission’s strategic significance, technological challenges, and its potential impact on India’s growing commercial and scientific presence in space. Moderated by veteran journalist and writer Vijay Mruthyunjaya, the session hopes to bring sharp insights, grounded analysis, and an inspiring look at the future trajectory of India’s space odyssey. 
From private-sector participation to international collaborations, and from orbital missions to deep space dreams, this discussion is your gateway to understanding how India is not just reaching for the stars, but preparing to stand among them.

name: Split Screens
description:
A daring literary experiment, explored through the eyes of the author herself! 
This evening authors Meena Kandasamy and Sam Arni will delve into the innovative split-screen structure of Kandasamy’s revolutionary book, Exquisite Cadavers. Together, they will discuss how experimentation of form confronts literary expectations, challenges the marginalization of writers from the Global South, and connects the intimate landscapes of relationships to broader public histories. 
Unlike a painter’s or potter’s studio where you can watch art come alive, the writer’s creative process is usually hidden, mysterious, almost alchemical. Exquisite Cadavers is Meena Kandasamy’s take on the novel-in-the-margins format. The story of Maya and Karim – lovers navigating the complexities of migration, racial identity, and political uncertainty in Brexit-era London – unfold only on half the pages. Juxtaposed with Kandasamy’s candid reflections on her own life experiences, the book provides a unique view into a writer’s process of creation. 
Join us for a disarmingly honest conversation on polemics, protests, and power.

name: Code Red: Climate in the Dock
description:
It’s here. The climate crisis is no longer a distant warning.  
Climate Change: The Policy, Law, and Practice is a vital intervention. A book that gathers decades of global negotiations, Indian legal battles, and emerging climate jurisprudence into one urgent and accessible narrative. From courtroom precedents to cutting-edge policy, from carbon markets to constitutional rights, it examines how law can both shape and respond to the climate emergency. 
Author and legal expert Jay Cheema draws from his experience as Amicus Curiae to the Supreme Court of India in a landmark carbon emissions case. Guiding us through the evolving legal architecture of climate action and accountability, his presentation will be followed by an incisive conversation with an interlocutor to explore the tensions and hopes within the climate discourse. An open Q&A will close the session. 
Reshaping landscapes, displacing lives, and challenging our very systems of governance, this crisis can no longer be sidelined. Forests burn where there was once monsoon green, rivers swell as glaciers retreat, and the ancient cycle of India’s six ritus feels increasingly unfamiliar. The chaos predicted by climate scientists in the 50’s is increasingly creeping into our reality.  
Because the climate crisis is not only legal and political, but deeply personal.

name: Populisms in India
description:
Is populism a threat or a corrective to democracy? Can it be both and at the same time? Is there an Indian Way of Populism? 
Much public commentary on populists has been pulled in different directions, and it seems almost impossible that we can cohere out of this polarized conundrum and into a shared understanding (even if disagreement) of meanings and labels around this concept. What indeed is the role of Populism in political modernization, and its place in a democracy, beyond the Americas and Europe? 
Populists are often understood in terms of who they are – rather who we think they are. This discussion will centre around a recent book “A Logic of Populism: India and its States” (Cambridge University Press 2025) that tries to understand populists in terms of what they do. Author, Srikrishna Ayyangar, argues that what populists do is to divide people, for the greater common good, and so who they are depends on political affiliations within the democratic context. Evoking the ‘Indian way’ inspired by A.K Ramanujan’s celebrated essay that the title of this discussion draws from, Ashutosh Varshney and Mahesh Rangarajan along with Sudhir Krishnaswamy as the moderator will engage in a conversation around the book and the relevance of the theme to India’s democracy.  A Q&A with the audience will follow. 
Tea will be served from 5 PM onwards.

name: Acts of Attention
description:
Can you write poetry about non-human life that doesn’t recall human life? If you’ve ever tried, you know it’s a feat of attention. There are few precedents. Japanese haikus come to mind as do short Sanskrit poems on bucolic animal and bird life. But these were exceptions even in their own literary contexts. 
You don’t have to read far into Chaucer’s 14th century poem Parliament of Fowls to realize that the bird characters are metaphors for humans. This also applies to Farid ud-Din Attar’s 12th century Persian Sufi classic, Conference of the Birds, as it does to the animal characters in the Sanskrit Hitopadesha. 
Siddhartha Menon’s poetry belongs to a modern practice, going back to around 1900, of creating poems through spells of intense attention to non-human life for its own sake. This evening will begin with a conversation between Menon and Prashant Keshavmurthy on how two of Menon’s six poem collections – The Compass Bird (2023) and Lone Pine (2025) – relate to this modern poetic practice. This will be followed by Menon’s readings from these collections, another conversation and then a discussion with the audience.

name: The Great Trigonometrical Survey
description:
A scientific quest, a vast subcontinent and an imperial impulse. 
The Great Trigonometrical Survey combined all these, resulting in one of the most astounding projects in the history of science. This talk by writer, Meera Iyer takes you through the GTS story, beginning with its origins in Bangalore and going all the way to the Himalayas. The intrepid surveyors handled devilishly delicate instruments, braved the monsoons, fell prey to disease, all in their quest for inch-perfect maps. Besides some of the most famous people in the GTS including William Lambton and George Everest, the talk will also speak about some of the forgotten Indians who were a part of this extraordinary work, and the relevance of the GTS today. 
A Q&A with the audience will follow.

name: The Worlds We Build
description:
Five picture bookmakers. One room full of ideas. 
Step into the imaginative world of children’s book illustration with Deepa Balsavar, Ogin Nayam, Pankaj Saikia, Priya Kuriyan, and Rajiv Eipe. All master storytellers who draw what they see, feel, and dream. 
This hands-on workshop offers a rare glimpse into their sketchbooks and creative journeys. Learn how everyday moments become unforgettable visuals, how characters come to life with just a few strokes of your brush, and how illustration transforms into storytelling. 
The session includes interactive demos, a Q&A with the artists, and a guided drawing activity that invites you to look closely, draw freely, and think like a storyteller. 
Join us and learn how to make your pictures worth more than a thousand words!

name: Mosaics of Motion
description:
Like ink on paper, a dancer on stage brings stories to life through gesture, rhythm, and the quiet intensity of perfection. 
In this specially curated evening, the National Youth Ballet Company presents a selection of Pas Seuls (solo variations) and ensemble works that celebrate both classic repertoire and fresh interpretation. Ballet, with its rich vocabulary of movement, is a timeless form of storytelling; one that carries emotion, history, and character in every turn and leap. From the mischievous Swanhilda of Coppélia to the grace of the Lilac Fairy from Sleeping Beauty, the bold spirit of Sylvia, the charm of the Nutcracker’s Tea Dance, and a fiery Jazz Waltz, each piece invites the audience into a world of layered characters and expressive movement. 
The evening culminates with excerpts from The Cave of Wonders; a preview of Aladdin The Ballet, the upcoming production by The Lewis Foundation of Classical Ballet. 
This event is an invitation to witness dedication, beauty, and the enduring power of dance.

name: The Expressive Companion: From Europe to India
description:
Born in Europe and reshaped in Calcutta, the harmonium arrived in India’s classical music world with baggage: too rigid, too foreign, and too limited. Critics called it unfit for the fluidity of Indian ragas. All India Radio banned it for thirty years.  
And yet, it endured. Its warm, resonant tones have become the soulful undercurrent to melodious ghazals, emotional bhajans, and classical ragas. 
This evening, journey through that remarkable evolution with Dr. Ravindra Katoti, one of India’s leading harmonium maestros, in conversation with celebrated vocalist Sri Dhananjay Hegde. With Sri Yogesh Bhat on tabla, they bring alive the stories, struggles, and triumphs of this powerful instrument. 
An evening of sound, memory, and musical legacy awaits.
